content.body: sideshowbarker: Is the https://github.com/w3c/mdn-spec-links project dead? It looks like it hasn't updated in two years, and now there are three specs listed in https://w3c.github.io/mdn-spec-links/SPECMAP.json whose files no longer exist in the repo.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: Is the https://github.com/w3c/mdn-spec-links project dead? It looks like it hasn't updated in two years, and now there are three specs listed in https://w3c.github.io/mdn-spec-links/SPECMAP.json whose files no longer exist in the repo.

content.body: Dead
Essentially, yes
is there a replacement? otherwise I need to just remove the MDN-panel feature from bikeshed
Please go ahead and remove it.
There's no replacement
If I could get somebody to take over maintenance on it, that would be great
Or to make a replacement
But in the meantime, let's just rip it out
kk, i'm just gonna check with our internal mdn people first

annevk: I've updated the out-of-order streaming explainer after the discussion about prepend last WHATNOT... 
https://github.com/WICG/declarative-partial-updates/blob/main/patching-explainer.md#interleaved-patching
In short, I think we still need append/replace-children as methods to allow multiple patches to the same element accumulate, and doing that with comments would be messy
content.formatted_body:
annevk: I've updated the out-of-order streaming explainer after the discussion about prepend last WHATNOT...
https://github.com/WICG/declarative-partial-updates/blob/main/patching-explainer.md#interleaved-patching
In short, I think we still need append/replace-children as methods to allow multiple patches to the same element accumulate, and doing that with comments would be messy

content.body: Oh, maybe the checker is wrong? /me finds https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10532
from what I recall of that, I maintain that the checker is in fact not wrong
that is, the checker is flagging an actual ‚Äútable integrity‚Äù error

but that said, the message is just a warning; and if the table-integrity ‚Äúerror‚Äù isn‚Äôt causing any known actual problems for anybody¬†trying to use the information in the ‚Äî¬†in particular, not for AT users especially, but also, not resulting in an visual breakage¬†‚Äî then the right (pragmatic) thing to do it, just ignore it
and also in general, it may be time for us to no longer be treating all checker warnings as errors ‚Äî as far as the spec builds go

Sorry about that. I was aware of it and at https://github.com/validator/validator/blob/main/build/build.py#L1281 ‚Äî in the whatwg-spec-build-check thing I added to the checker CI ‚Äî I am filtering that warning out. But it should have occurred to me that would not fix it for the actual upstream whatwg builds. I guess that was because I had been (wrongly) assuming the builds were only failing on checker errors, but not on warnings.

We don't fail on "info warnings" it seems, which is why HTML is still going strong. I think I agree with you that this Jake diagram pattern is suspicious. At least the HTML standard makes no mention of a "missing cell" concept.
The language guesser that the checker uses¬†‚Äî¬†and I think that in general, all other such language guessers, as a class¬†‚Äî¬†do not operate predictably on non-prose text content.
One mitigation I already have the language guesser in the checker tuned to do, is to just not try to operate on any text content that is less than about ~200 words (1024 characters).

‚Ä¶but that doesn‚Äôt help for the case where there is more than 1024 characters of completely no-prose text content. Which under normal real-world cases is a highly exceptional case. But those Encoding spec legacy-coverage files are highly exceptional in a lot of ways‚Ä¶

So one thing I want to suggest considering is: For the Encoding spec, we change the build to only running the HTML checker on the spec index.html file itself ‚Äî¬†and not on any of those (dozens) of other legacy-coverage files (which are anyway just big tables of characters, or whatever they are)

Alternatively, I am fairly certain I could tune the language guesser further such that we could make it end up just completely not trying to do any language-guessing at all on content of those Encoding legacy-coverage files.

And lastly I will say that I personally have zero love for maintaining that language-guessing (mis)feature of the HTML checker anyway, and my life would be somewhat easier if I could just rip that feature out entirely.

‚Ä¶but what stops me from doing that is the fact it‚Äôs an accessibility-related use case ‚Äî¬†specifically, trying to make sure that people aren‚Äôt just cargo-cult-copying lang=en into every document, despite the actual language of the document‚Äôs content)
In other words, it‚Äôs not something I added to the checker myself on a whim. And I don‚Äôt have any replacement for it at hand that would do the job any better.
